description: The <select> element provides a menu of options for a user to pick from, typically rendered as a dropdown list.
description_html: The <select> element provides a menu of options for a user to pick from, typically rendered as a dropdown list.
name: <select>

safari.notes: The property can be set, but has no effect (see bug 227042).

safari_ios.notes: The property can be set, but has no effect (see bug 227042).

webview_ios.notes: The property can be set, but has no effect (see bug 227042).

ie.notes: Before Internet Explorer 9, the outerHTML of elements lose their text when constructing with new Option().

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 7 the label property incorrectly returned an empty string if not defined instead of returning the element's text content.

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox for Android 7 the label property incorrectly returned an empty string if not defined instead of returning the element's text content.

firefox.notes: You should watch for change events on <select> instead of watching <option> elements for events. See bug 1090602 and Multiprocess Firefox Web content compatibility for details.

edge.notes: namedItem does not appear to take the name attribute into account (only the id attribute) on Internet Explorer and Edge. There is a bug report to Microsoft about this.

ie.notes: namedItem does not appear to take the name attribute into account (only the id attribute) on Internet Explorer and Edge. There is a bug report to Microsoft about this.

safari.notes: Before Safari 7, the attribute can be set, but has no effect.

safari_ios.notes: The attribute can be set, but has no effect.

webview_ios.notes: The attribute can be set, but has no effect.

notes: Before 77, Firefox didn't display the value of the label attribute as option text if element's content was empty. See bug 40545.

Historically, Firefox has allowed keyboard and mouse events to bubble up from the <option> element to the parent <select> element, although this behavior is inconsistent across many browsers. For better Web compatibility (and for technical reasons), they will not bubble up when Firefox is in multi-process mode and the <select> element is displayed as a drop-down list. The behavior is unchanged if the <select> is presented inline and it has either the multiple attribute defined or a size attribute set to more than 1. Rather than watching <option> elements for events, you should watch for change events on <select>. See bug 1090602 for details.

When Mozilla introduced dedicated content threads to Firefox (through the Electrolysis, or e10s, project), support for styling <option> elements was removed temporarily. Starting in Firefox 54, you can apply foreground and background colors to <option> elements again, using the color and background-color CSS properties. See bug 910022 for more information. Note that this is still disabled in Linux due to lack of contrast (see bug 1338283 for progress on this).

firefox_android.notes: Before 77, Firefox didn't display the value of the label attribute as option text if element's content was empty. See bug 40545.

chrome.notes: border-radius on <select> elements is ignored unless -webkit-appearance is overridden to an appropriate value.

chrome_android.notes: border-radius on <select> elements is ignored unless -webkit-appearance is overridden to an appropriate value.

firefox.notes: Historically, Firefox has allowed keyboard and mouse events to bubble up from the <option> element to the parent <select> element, although this behavior is inconsistent across many browsers. For better Web compatibility (and for technical reasons), when Firefox is in multi-process mode the <select> element is displayed as a drop-down list. The behavior is unchanged if the <select> is presented inline and it has either the multiple attribute defined or a size attribute set to more than 1. Rather than watching <option> elements for events, you should watch for change events on <select>. See bug 1090602 for details.

firefox_android.notes: Firefox for Android, by default, sets a background-image gradient on all <select multiple> elements. This can be disabled using background-image: none.

oculus.notes: border-radius on <select> elements is ignored unless -webkit-appearance is overridden to an appropriate value.

notes: Only exposes the <hr> visually in the page when the menu is expanded (arrowing within the collapsed menu does not show them).
Does not expose the <hr> within the accessibility tree.
